content: Dennis Kucinich really took the TARP fund overseer (Can't remember his name, but it starts with a K) to task over how the TARP funds have been spent. He pointedly asked if a bank which has received TARP money investing in Dubai is considered by the Treasury to be a legitimate use of that money an in the nations best interest. "K" hemmed and hawed but eventually came up with the explanation that Treasury has gone out of its way not to micro-manage the banks which we've leant money to and, if they invest overseas, it will make the bank more profitable and better able to pay back the "loan" we gave them. In other words, We The People just gave them an interest free loan to make more money and Treasury doesn't give a damn how they do it!

content: I will have to ask Dennis about that next time I talk to him. Either way, if that is going to make Citi more solvent, then I do not see a problem. It would be dumb for any bank to lend to Americans right now for two reasons: Americans are completely tapped out as it is and they're defaulting on the loans they already have. The only alignments that most corporations have is to make their shareholders as much money as possible. And, that is what Citi is attempting to do. It is just that cannot be done in America right now. That is just obvious. It would be effective suicide for Citi to start lending here in the States and they know that. As for the Treasury not giving a darn how the money is spent. Well, maybe there should have been more earmarks in that bill or the bill should have been more specific. I always find it funny that most of the people who are now taking the protectionist route are the same ones who have accused me of being an isolationist. Most of you support the idea of spreading our military influence around the world, but don't do business outside of the US. Whereas I say do as much business and trade around the world as possible, but keep our military here at home. You guys really do crack me up sometimes. What's even funnier is that most of you are the same ones who wouldn't have believe a single word that Kucinich said only a few months ago. This forum is starting to wreak of hypocrisy and BS more and more everyday. Just out of curiosity, how in the hell do you expect Citi and the other banks to pay back the TARP money? Apparently the answer I am seeing is to loan money to people who can't pay back the loan and create jobs that are going to be a liability.

content: This talk of a one-world currency, etc is just ignorant. First of all, all money is fiat money, except if you're going to barter. 5 goats for 10 chickens, that sort of thing. Money is just whatever value people assign to something - makes no difference if it's paper or metal. Secondly, it's a good thing we went off the gold standard, as we were running out of gold as countries were converting dollars into gold. Further, a fixed exchange rate doesn't work for long. And that is why we are on a floating exchange rate today, because it works better. That is why other countries let their currencies float as well. And why more, like China, are moving toward that. It works better for economies that way, because it doesn't work in the long run when you try to fix prices at a certain level. It is much more beneficial to have many currencies, which are floating, and benefits no one, not rich nor poor, to have a "one world" currency. It isn't going to happen, no one is trying to make it happen, and it's crazy and ignorant to think that's what happening.

content: I am speaking of fiat in relation to representative currency. Our current fiat system is not represented by anything but debt. If everybody were to pay off all debts, there would be no money in circulation. And, I don't think anybody recommended price fixing. As a matter of fact, the research info that I posted in my last post completely blasts price fixing and shows it's downfall. "This is the shabby secret of the welfare statists' tirades against gold. Deficit spending is simply a scheme for the confiscation of wealth. Gold stands in the way of this insidious process. It stands as a protector of property rights. If one grasps this, one has no difficulty in understanding the statists' antagonism toward the gold standard." Alan Greenspan Also, we were indeed running out of Gold in the 30s. But, that is not due to the system itself. It was due to the initiatives of the Roosevelt administration to get us off of the Gold Standard. That process was indeed legislated and it's process continues until Nixon put the nail in the coffin. content: What our current fiat system is represented by is value of labor, not debt. It does not matter if it's paper or metal. I work 8 hours a day, I can be paid in X units of gold or Y units of dollars, it doesn't matter which. It is the LABOR that ANY monetary system represents, because as a society, labor is what we value. Debt is just a way in which a person says, ok my time is worth X units of dollars or Y units of gold, and I want to purchase this house(for example) and I am willing to devote 30 years of my time for this dwelling. Debt is simply a way of which a person arbitrarily and voluntarily assigns an upper limit on what he can accomplish(or conversely a lower limit for others), but it is not representative of what the currency represents. Labor is representative of that. The value of work. And since labor is representative of whatever our currency happens to be, assuming all debts were paid off, are you saying that my labor could then not buy anything? Of course it could. As for Greenspan's comment, can you elaborate a little and explain what you you interpret as him saying in that comment? How exactly does gold protect property rights? This message has been edited. Last edited by: DCookeUSA1, Thu 12 March 2009 04:08 PM

content: Here's another way to think about it - think of labor as representative of debt. If I owe money on a credit card, I have agreed to devote a certain amount of time and labor, whatever it may be, to repay my debt to that company. I decide for myself what the value of my labor is. Conversely, if others are in debt to me, they have agreed to a certain amount of time and labor to pay off their debt to me. In this case, I assign for others what I think the value of their labor is. But even if there WERE no debt, I could still assign a value for what I think my labor is worth, and by working, produce said value. Others could do the same. So debt is a way by which I say my labor is worth X and will CONTINUE to be worth X for a certain period in the future.

content: soscorpio, the banker may leverage 1 dollar to lend out 9, but the banker doesn't keep that money. It's passed on to investors. Most of it, anyway. Anyone who can afford the security can buy a mortgage backed security - here's an example right off the fannie mae website. --http://fapt.efanniemae.com/eprosupp2/RetrievePDF.jsp It probably is, in a sense, a type of serf system. But here's the difference - no one is in physical shackles, people can stop paying at any time, but more importantly, the environment is there where a person can most easily empower himself or herself through education and break the shackle of debt. So you can buy your financial freedom. At a million or two you can write your own ticket in life. That's what I think America is about - an environment where the individual can empower himself or herself, if the individual chooses to. Plus I think it's a mistake to try to forcefully "empower" anyone, it can easily lead to tyranny. The "liberty" part of "life liberty and pursuit of happiness" is still there, because you are free to empower yourself, if you choose.

content: I will have to ask Dennis about that next time I talk to him. Either way, if that is going to make Citi more solvent, then I do not see a problem. It would be dumb for any bank to lend to Americans right now for two reasons: Americans are completely tapped out as it is and they're defaulting on the loans they already have. The only alignments that most corporations have is to make their shareholders as much money as possible. And, that is what Citi is attempting to do. It is just that cannot be done in America right now. That is just obvious. It would be effective suicide for Citi to start lending here in the States and they know that. As for the Treasury not giving a darn how the money is spent. Well, maybe there should have been more earmarks in that bill or the bill should have been more specific. I always find it funny that most of the people who are now taking the protectionist route are the same ones who have accused me of being an isolationist. Most of you support the idea of spreading our military influence around the world, but don't do business outside of the US. Whereas I say do as much business and trade around the world as possible, but keep our military here at home. You guys really do crack me up sometimes. What's even funnier is that most of you are the same ones who wouldn't have believe a single word that Kucinich said only a few months ago. This forum is starting to wreak of hypocrisy and BS more and more everyday. Just out of curiosity, how in the hell do you expect Citi and the other banks to pay back the TARP money? Apparently the answer I am seeing is to loan money to people who can't pay back the loan and create jobs that are going to be a liability.

content: This talk of a one-world currency, etc is just ignorant. First of all, all money is fiat money, except if you're going to barter. 5 goats for 10 chickens, that sort of thing. Money is just whatever value people assign to something - makes no difference if it's paper or metal. Secondly, it's a good thing we went off the gold standard, as we were running out of gold as countries were converting dollars into gold. Further, a fixed exchange rate doesn't work for long. And that is why we are on a floating exchange rate today, because it works better. That is why other countries let their currencies float as well. And why more, like China, are moving toward that. It works better for economies that way, because it doesn't work in the long run when you try to fix prices at a certain level. It is much more beneficial to have many currencies, which are floating, and benefits no one, not rich nor poor, to have a "one world" currency. It isn't going to happen, no one is trying to make it happen, and it's crazy and ignorant to think that's what happening.

content: I am speaking of fiat in relation to representative currency. Our current fiat system is not represented by anything but debt. If everybody were to pay off all debts, there would be no money in circulation. And, I don't think anybody recommended price fixing. As a matter of fact, the research info that I posted in my last post completely blasts price fixing and shows it's downfall. "This is the shabby secret of the welfare statists' tirades against gold. Deficit spending is simply a scheme for the confiscation of wealth. Gold stands in the way of this insidious process. It stands as a protector of property rights. If one grasps this, one has no difficulty in understanding the statists' antagonism toward the gold standard." Alan Greenspan Also, we were indeed running out of Gold in the 30s. But, that is not due to the system itself. It was due to the initiatives of the Roosevelt administration to get us off of the Gold Standard. That process was indeed legislated and it's process continues until Nixon put the nail in the coffin. And, the transcripts to the Newshour story: ---URL=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/business/jan-june09/regulationchanges_03.html]http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/business/jan-june09/regulationchanges_03.html

content: What our current fiat system is represented by is value of labor, not debt. It does not matter if it's paper or metal. I work 8 hours a day, I can be paid in X units of gold or Y units of dollars, it doesn't matter which. It is the LABOR that ANY monetary system represents, because as a society, labor is what we value. Debt is just a way in which a person says, ok my time is worth X units of dollars or Y units of gold, and I want to purchase this house(for example) and I am willing to devote 30 years of my time for this dwelling. Debt is simply a way of which a person arbitrarily and voluntarily assigns an upper limit on what he can accomplish(or conversely a lower limit for others), but it is not representative of what the currency represents. Labor is representative of that. The value of work. And since labor is representative of whatever our currency happens to be, assuming all debts were paid off, are you saying that my labor could then not buy anything? Of course it could. As for Greenspan's comment, can you elaborate a little and explain what you you interpret as him saying in that comment? How exactly does gold protect property rights? This message has been edited. content: Here's another way to think about it - think of labor as representative of debt. If I owe money on a credit card, I have agreed to devote a certain amount of time and labor, whatever it may be, to repay my debt to that company. I decide for myself what the value of my labor is. Conversely, if others are in debt to me, they have agreed to a certain amount of time and labor to pay off their debt to me. In this case, I assign for others what I think the value of their labor is. But even if there WERE no debt, I could still assign a value for what I think my labor is worth, and by working, produce said value. Others could do the same. So debt is a way by which I say my labor is worth X and will CONTINUE to be worth X for a certain period in the future.

content: soscorpio, the banker may leverage 1 dollar to lend out 9, but the banker doesn't keep that money. It's passed on to investors. Most of it, anyway. Anyone who can afford the security can buy a mortgage backed security - here's an example right off the fannie mae website. --http://fapt.efanniemae.com/eprosupp2/RetrievePDF.jsp It probably is, in a sense, a type of serf system. But here's the difference - no one is in physical shackles, people can stop paying at any time, but more importantly, the environment is there where a person can most easily empower himself or herself through education and break the shackle of debt. So you can buy your financial freedom. At a million or two you can write your own ticket in life. That's what I think America is about - an environment where the individual can empower himself or herself, if the individual chooses to. Plus I think it's a mistake to try to forcefully "empower" anyone, it can easily lead to tyranny. The "liberty" part of "life liberty and pursuit of happiness" is still there, because you are free to empower yourself, if you choose.
